comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Possibly another of Badier's pics of Circular Quay which he took in ?early to mid 1887, whilst he was still at Newtown. acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=421243 an earlier pic which shows all the warehouses and wool stores we see here (apart from Hill Clark & Co). www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4930536367/ in 1870 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article108832985 - Hill Clark & Co warehouse...tenders for construction accepted October 1883; nla.gov.au/nla.news-article64035874 the finished product. Various digitised newspaper hits (search under 'City Improvements' and 'Flood') indicate that excavation work on the foundations of Edward Flood's Balckwall Stores was underway in January 1864 (which suggest the excavation might have started in late 1863)...the construction had reached the level of the first floor in ca. May 1864...and was nearing completion in February 1865...there was a fairly substantial fire at the Blackwall Stores in 1870 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article70457651 ...but the outer walls appear to have escaped unscathed...and the stores survived well into the 20th century. The Talbot stores were built on either side of what later became the Moore Steps thoroughfare. Various digitised newspaper hits (search under 'City Improvements' and 'Talbot') indicate the Talbot Stores were under construction in February 1863...but it's not clear whether both Talbot stores were all built at this time...Talbot came into conflict with municipal authorities in 1867 when the council decided to build the Moore Steps...per the digitised newspapers, a wall on one of the stores (then under construction) toppled when council workers filled in a partly excavated cellar...which didn't exactly impress Talbot. Hitherto Talbot had evidently had the run of the thoroughfare between his stores, and he wasn't happy with the council decision to build the stairs and improve public access to East Circular Quay...enough there for a TV mini series... Does anyone have any info on the ?house/building between the Hill Clark & Co warehouse and the Blackwall stores? It seems to have been there for eons.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] That house/building is not marked on most 19th century maps, except this wonderful 1822 map - it could be "30 - the Water-bailiff's Residence". I am thinking it might have survived redevelopment for a long time because it was a government building. Interactive 1822 map - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview/?pi=nla.map-f107-sd&rgn=0....

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] That's great! ...I'd say the Water Bailiff's residence is looking good!...I wonder what it became known as later in the century. Also appears in these pics acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=414320 ; acms.sl.nsw.gov.au//item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=420858

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Lovely! Thanks folks. The little house is a sweet recurring feature.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] They aren't arranged next to each other, but a few pages apart. The little number in square brackets in the caption gives you some idea of the ordering in the album. I think there is a Government House panorama coming up, and these images come from either end of the album.
